params.text: Design techniques and weaving centers
"Women help each other comb and arrange the warp yards"

• Virtually all the towns of Ilocos Norte had nurtured the tradition of textile weaving. Each town specialized in a particular textile weaving design technique employing the pangablan-Ilocano loom or the pedal frame loom.

Technically, the art of textile weaving lies in the designs and in the manner by which the designs are produced. Textile weaving is simply the interlocking of vertical yarns (warp) known as gan-ay and horizontal yarns (weft) known as pakan.

However, the laying-out of design for textile weaving begins prior to the weaving process itself. The arrangement of warp yarns using the gagan-ayan or warping frame principally determines the breadth, thinness, or thickness of the textile to be woven and the general character (Cg. color composition) of the ground weave. The arranged warp yarns are then individually inserted into each eye of the stringed-heddle or gur-on and then into each slat of the sugod or reed
"Inserting threads into the wooden reed"
"Arranging of warp yards using the wrapping frame"
DIFFERENT DESIGNS
PLAIN WEAVING
BROCADE WEAVING
MULTI-HEDDLE WEAVE
TIE-DYING DESIGN

params.text: PLAIN WEAVING

• Just by employing colored yarns for the warp and/or weft, plain woven designs of stripes technique which is known as tinartaros among Ilocano weavers, creates endless possible compositions in stripes and plaids.

• The banderado which is very much identified as Ilocano weave is a 3-4 paneled blanket done in plain weave design technique. It usually features a single color band of either black or red or yellow on white ground, or two to three color-band combinations of either red and black or yellow and green or red, green/blue, and yellow or white ground. The minimal color scheme in the banderado heightens the stark simplicity of the design and echoes the terse yet practical sensibility of the northern Ilocano-a people engaged in trading, fishing, and farming small individual fields, Bacarra, Laoag,  Dingras are recognized for their well-woven, thick, hand-spun cotton banderado.

• Also done in plain weave design technique are the kinurkuros or plaided textiles which are sewn into pandiling-wide long skirts, bado- dresses and upper garmentS such as barongs. The kinurkuros are of fine cotton yarn but it is not rare to find horizontal bands of plaids in silk. Almost every town in llocos Norte excels in the weaving kinurkuros but the weavers of Laoag, Sarrat, Dingras, Banna and Pinili are noted for their all-refreshing design compositions.

params.text: BROCADE WEAVING

• Brocade or Pinilian, Produces designs or patterns that float in relief on the surface of the cloth. Pinilian designs are formed by either continuous or discontinuous supplementary weft yarns. Continuous supplementary weft yarns are carried by the sikkuan or a wooden double-horn-edged shuttle that runs across the whole breadth of the warp while interlocking with selected warp yarns designated by design sticks known as serpit or pili.
"Continuous and discontinuous brocade pinilian make use of design sticks to create the design forms"

• The supplementary weft is usually thick as it is made up of multiple strands of yarns, while the principal weft is of fine double strand yarn. The latter is always carried by a boat-shaped shuttle or karilyas across the whole breadth of the warp from selvage to selvage to form at the ground weave.

  • The weavers of Pinili and Paoay are practitioners of continuous supplementary wet brocade pinilian design technique. Most featured designs are the sinan-bulong or palm leaf and sinan-lopis or cotton ball. The popularity of the two mentioned designs underscores the abundance of these plants in Ilocos Norte and signifies their importance and value in the life of the northern Ilocanos. Brocade-pinilian weaving utilizes several design sticks.

  • A variation of the continuous supplementary weft brocade pinilian is the in-laid design technique locally termed inkaot or insukit. Selected warp yarns designated by serpit or pili design sticks when raised by the waver, create open sheds among the warp yarns, where discontinuous supplementary weft yarns are inserted by the weaver's fingers. The process enables the weaver to use several colors of supplementary weft yarns in a single design composition or in a row of design forms.

  • The inkaot or insukit design technique also allows the weavers to form well-modeled curvilinear figures such as sinan-tao (human figure), sinan-baggak (morning star), sinan-kippi (crab), inik-ikan (fishes), sinan-pabo (turkey) and sinan-gikgik (double headed and yellow legged bird or chicken). It is significant to note that the latter is also featured in the llocano epic. It is one of the pets of the hero Lam-ang endowed with supernatural powers.

  • To some Ilocanos, particularly the weavers of Paoay, the yellow-legged bird or chicken locally known as karurayan is believed to be a vehicle of anitos or spirits that may bring either good luck or bad luck. Thus it is both revered and feared. By featuring it in the textiles, especially blankets as bed covers, the sinan-gik- gik or yellow legged bird or chicken is propitiated and appeased. In the Ilocano epic, the yellow-legged bird or chicken is one of the good luck charms of the hero Lam-ang.

  • The weavers of barangay Nalasin and Mapusdo in Paoay are the main keepers of the tradition of inkaot or insukit, discontinuous supplementary weft brocade pinilian employed in textiles utilized blankets, bed covers, table covers or mantles, valance and curtains.
SAMPLE BROCADE DESIGN

params.text: MULTI-HEDDLE WEAVE

Textured ground designs are produced in the multiple-heddle design technique locally known as tinumbalitian (Banna and Pinili), or kinomit (Pasuquin, Bacarra and Vintar) and tiubugan or binutuagan (Sarrat and Piddig). The multi-heddle design technique employs node length bamboos attached to the heddles to function as weights for tighter interlocking of yarns and to keep in place the open skeds where weft yarns and to keep in place the open sheds where weft yarns are passed through. Usually 3-8 in number, the heddles take the place of design sticks

The heddles are attached by strings to the pedals utilized in brocade pinilian design technique of the pangablan enabling their easy manipulation and effecting a convenient working style for the weaver.

The binnaliktad or face to face weave is also produced in the multi-heddle design technique. Both surfaces (front and back) of the cloth exhibit finely textured designs of sina- gipang or balilaw (spindle), interlocking or intersecting circles, kinarkarot (wild root crop), and sinan-sabong (flowers). A recent creation by master weaver Aida Fernandez, done in a multi- heddle design technique, depicts large flowers that are highly textured.

• The multi-heddle design technique is traditionally applied in blanket weaves. The blankets are either single-hued or plain white. The latter, which are popularly known as kundiman, are often used as luante or backdrop of a makeshift altar during religious processions such as the station of the cross in lent, and in flores de mayo. At present, the multi-heddle weave is re-employed by Paoay weavers to produce finely textured cloths for bado (dresses), jackets, chalekos and skirts.
  • The binitbituka is a design of geometric patterns produced by 6-8 heddle. The patterns are an alternation of projecting and recessed forms resulting in an overall design that is strongly tactile in effect and appeal. The textured forms show a strong resemblance to the inner lining of the pig's stomach; thus the design is termed binitbituka mainly by Sarrat and also Vintar weavers.
  • The tinarlinga is another design produced in the multi-heddle design technique. Practiced mainly by Paoay weavers, the design is made-up of raised horizontal lines creating an interesting contrast to the plain ground. The overall effect is a series of ridges or waves.

params.text: TIE-DYING DESIGN

Tie-dyeing known worldwide as ikat is the design technique where certain areas on the length of the yarn (warp and/or weft) is bound with a string or other yarn material, functioning as dye resist, after which the skeins of tied yarn are immersed in a dye solution.

• A most interesting weave by Ilocanos is the binakul. It is done in plain weave design technique. It utilizes double- hued weft usually in black and white or green and white, or blue and white, and sometimes in red and white. The patterns formed are an alteration of negative (black/green/blue/red) and positive (white) squares and rectangles of graduated sizes. The most popular binakul design is the kusikus (whirlpool) or alipugpug (whirlwind). The squares and rectangles form optical illusions of concentric circles in perpetual movement fully equating the incessant circuitous movement of the whirlpool and/or the whirlwind. The engaging kusikus or alipugpug design is also depicted in side-view as seen in the pinal-pal-id (fan) design of the binakul.

In a limited way the weavers of Ilocos Norte practiced warp ikat known locally as rinimasan-tied with string (the root word rimas is derivative of ripas-string) referring to the process of tying with string. Until the early 1960s Ilocos Norte weavers were regularly supplied tie-dyed yarns by itinerant traders from Mangaldan, Pangasinan. The Ilocos Norte weavers had to removė the bound strings, and then weave, to produce exquisite cloth with warp and weft ikat. The designs were simple double or triple streaks of lines forming either stripes or plaids on a ground of deep indigo (from tayum) and red (from sapang dye stuff). Laoag weavers are noted to have greatly produced rinimasan textiles for pandiling or wide long skirts.

 

The tiniri or twisted yarns of different hues employed sparingly in the weft produce an effect similar to tie-dye or rinimasan, Sarrat weavers do the tiniri for bado-dresses and polo.
